An update on the player#s condition # which suggested he suffered a skull fracture # was shared on the Newtonmore Camanachd Facebook site on Sunday afternoon.Fowler had helped his team to a - victory over last year#s Camanachd and MacTavish Cup winners.Iain Robinson got the opening goal after  minutes, rling in at the back post after a corner from the impressive winger Drew MacDonald.Jordan Fraser swept home a Keith MacRae cross to level matters on  minutes, but Max Campbell restored the visitors# lead in the nd minute, and veteran Fraser MacKintosh netted from long range just before half time to put Newtonmore # who were without Mike Russell and Craig Ritchie due to Covid # in command.The lack of pre-season action looked as though it had taken its toll, and Shiel never found their rhythm in a fragmented second half interupted by injuries.#More attacker Iain Robinson suffered a dislocated shoulder, a back problem forced off Shiel striker John MacRae, while defender David Falconer#s afternoon was ended early by a hamstring problem.Kinlochshiel manager Johnston Gill said: #We never reached half the level we did last season, and against a team like Newtonmore that isn#t enough.#We can play better, and we will play better as we get more games under our belts, but it#s a disappointing start to lose at home.#Newtonmore co-manager Norman MacArthur was delighted at his team#s display # with Steven MacDonald and Rory Kennedy outstanding in defence.He said: #We came over with no expectations # but the young boys who came in were fantastic. To get our season underway with a win at the Scottish champions is a great way to start.#ELSEWHERE ON SATURDAY, Mowi Premier League champions Kingussie got off to a flyer with Savio Genini scoring four in a - home rout of Caberfeidh.Lovat and Oban Camanachd each recorded - away wins at Kilmallie and Glasgow Mid Argyll respectively, while Kyles Athletic recovered from two down to salvage a - draw with Fort William at An Aird.In the National Division Skye Camanachd fell behind to a Daniel MacMillan strike after  minutes, but goals from Jordan Murchison on  and John Gillies on  minutes proved enoough to earn the islanders victory against Oban Celtic.Euan MacCormick scored four as Beauly set the pace in the ision by putting nine without reply past Aberdour.Lochaber edged Strathglass by the odd goal in five at Cannich, while Inveraray and Glenurquhart shared the points after a - draw at the Winterton.

title: tobar an dualchais what can proverbs tell us about
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineIn recent years, interest in this concept has been growing exponentially, with a iety of groups recognising its importance as a sense of place and belonging or identying it as the rootedness us modern people are understandably desperate for. which Edward Dwelly noted in his dictionary.The Place of one#s birth.Heredity, native or hereditary temper, spirit or blood.Visage, countenance.Hereditary right. could be one of the cornerstones of a reconstructed Gaelic worldview. The identity of a person could undoubtedly be forged by the place of their birth and the community of that place, particularly at a time in the past when populations were less mobile.The traits of a person’s parents manest in their physical appearance their spirit, likes and dislikes, and sometimes even interests or inclinations might appear hereditary – not just from mother and father but perhaps from an ancestor remembered only by name and special characteristic, like poesy or craft skill..The failure by clan chiefs and other landed gentry to recognise this customary right held by the people since time immemorial underpins the Clearances, while demands for its recognition echo through much of the collective action undertaken against this violence, trauma, and dispossession. as far back in history as I can.The world and society these people lived in was so dferent to ours today, making context crucial to understanding the words being used and the philosophy from which they derive.Aside from the multitude which are in still in use today, there are published proverb collections as well as countless sound recordings, many digitized and made easily accessible by Tobar an Dualchais.By their nature proverbs cut across boundaries of class and gender, their survival relying upon oral transmission, on being commonly known in a community and thus reflecting its values. They are that memorable phrase we hear our elders say once they have explained its meaning to us, we are unlikely to forget it.Theyto us often and roll off the tongue.One of the most important collections of Gaelic proverbs was published in  by Alexander Nicolson .However, Nicolson was merely re-printing a collection made by Donald Macintosh, a Perthshire-born clergyman, first printed in Edinburgh in . Nicolson called the collection “a genuine product of the past” with Macintosh merely acting as collator and translator. of Islay, perhaps coined in the times when the MacLeans, MacDonalds, and later Campbells feuded over the island the second one is a rhyme about the MacAlpines, their former seat in Dunstaffnage, and their ancient claim to the throne of Scotland:When the natives forsake Islay, farewell the peace of Scotland!Children of the native kings, Who reigned down at Dunstaffnage, Who first the crown of Alba owned, And still have native claim to it..It also tells us that there are always grave, far-reaching political consequences whenever an indigenous population is forced to abandon its home.as a hereditary right can last for centuries. The strength of attachment to people and place shines through both.Blood is stronger than breeding., ‘blood is thicker than water’, and perhaps it should come as no surprise to us that a society which places strong emphasis on ancestry and blood ties should have so many proverbs reinforcing such beliefs..Sad is the inheritance of a bad disease.This proverb is the perfect reminder that not everything we inherit from our ancestors is good. Psychologically and spiritually, we inherit their trauma physically, as the proverb reminds us, we may inherit their medical conditions.By accepting the full extent of our inheritance – strength and weakness, the beautul and the ugly – we grow closer to our ancestors and empower ourselves to heal from what they could not.has always been characterised by plurality and complexity, reflecting the complex Gàidhealtachd to which it belonged.For centuries, fostering children has been an important feature of Gaelic society, and for all the influence that DNA can have on us, the nurture we receive during our formative years has just as much –not more – influence on who we become within our community.In a changing world, it is inspiring to see people across the Gàidhealtachd connecting with the cultural ‘mycelium’ of their place and rooting themselves in it, whether it is their ancestral homeland or adoptive home.can be a wellspring of transformative energy for place-based revitalisation.Sometimes it seems to burst like lightning, explosively cleaving through adversity. But it is also the stream – the carrying stream – slowly weathering stone, flowing ever on from generation to generation.

title: council commends autism friendly sessions at local attraction
story: MID and East Antrim Borough Council has commended a local business on the launch of a new initiative aimed at autistic children and their families. Commencing on Wednesday  March, Fun Factory Ballymena will host a series of quiet play sessions for autistic children, during which visitor entry numbers will be signicantly reduced, lighting will be dimmed and no loud music will be played. A six-month pilot of the initiative, which is supported by Council’s Community Planning Partnership, will see the sessions offered on the last Wednesday of every month between March and October from .pm to .pm . The sessions align with Mid and East Antrim Borough Council’s strategy to make Mid and East Antrim an Autism Friendly Borough as part of its Community Plan. Partnering with a wide range of organisations, including The Fun Factory, Council is creating a strong, vibrant, safe and inclusive community in which local citizens, businesses and community organisations work together to improve the lives of everyone. Council remains strongly committed to ensuring Mid and East Antrim is an accessible, safe, welcoming and inclusive place for every person living in or visiting the Borough. In , it was awarded the prestigious ‘Autism Impact Award’ for six of its venues in recognition of “going above and beyond” to create accessible and ‘autism-friendly’ environments – including Seven Towers Leisure Centre and The People’s Park. These award accreditations were presented by Autism NI, in partnership with the Northern Health and Social Care Trust .Pamela, Manager of The Fun Factory, commented: “The Fun Factory is very much behind Council’s ambition to be as accessible and inclusive as possible for every person of every age, background and ability living in or visiting our Mid and East Antrim – it’s something we very much strive to achieve in our own business. “We passionately believe that every child deserves the chance to have a fun and enjoyable experience in an environment in which they feel safe and comfortable. Council has been fantastic in helping us to understand the challenges faced by autistic children and their families and supporting us to develop these new quiet play sessions.”For more information about the sessions, please visit www.thefunfactoryni. Sessions can be booked via telephone by calling   .

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220329newsbooster third dose milestone welcomed
story: The number of COVID- vaccine boosters and third doses administered in Northern Ireland has passed the one million mark. The milestone has been welcomed by Patricia Donnelly, head of Northern Ireland’s vaccination programme. She said: “GPs, community pharmacists and Trusts have all worked extremely hard to roll out the booster campaign, with the period in the run up to Christmas particularly busy. “They all deserve our heartfelt thanks. Because of the vaccines, we now have much greater protection against the virus. “All those involved in the vaccination programme are genuine history makers.” Booster doses have been provided from the latter stages of last year, supplementing the two primary doses already received. At the same time, a third primary dose was offered to people with a severely weakened immune system, which was then followed by a booster three months after their third primary dose. The latest tallies on Northern Ireland’s vaccination dashboard include , boosters and , third doses. Patriciacontinued: “While demand for vaccines is no longer at levels from the peak of the campaign, people are still coming forward on a daily basis for boosters and first and second doses. “It’s still not too late to get these jabs. Please do so - and benefit from the really important protection they bring.” The one million landmark has been reached with the Spring booster campaign imminent. In line with UK-wide guidance set by the JCVI, the Spring campaign will offer an additional booster dose to: anyone who is aged  or over care home residents and anyone aged  and over who has a severely weakened immune system. Further details can be found on NI Direct:www.nidirect.gov.uk articles get-covid--vaccination-and-booster-northern-ireland

title: wrightbus continues recruitment search with 50 new jobs
story: WORLD leading bus manufacturer Wrightbus is hosting a recruitment evening on Thursdayas it continues to bolster its ranks with an additional  staff after an increase in orders.The Ballymena-based company is launching the second phase of its recruitment drive ready for an increase in the production schedule after Easter. It has attracted hundreds of people to similar events held earlier this year, with numerous job offers made on the spot after express interviews.Wrightbus’ recruitment evenings provide prospective employees with the opportunity to look around the company’s Galgorm factory and speak to company managers and the HR team about potential career opportunities.The firm had previously announced it was looking to recruit an additional  people as orders for its buses flooded in. This time, it’s especially keen to attract more women.“We’ve taken on a number of new staff so far this year, which is fantastic - but we still have roles available that we need to fill,” said Wrightbus HR director, Nicola McCloskey.“Our staff work in great conditions on some of the world’s leading zero emission technology, which is helping to make a real dference to climate change.“We’re especially keen to get more women into the workforce, as most of the interest we’ve had to date has been from men. “I think there’s a bit of a misconception that the work we do here is all very physically demanding, but we’ve got many dferent roles across the factory.“We’d encourage anyone interested in joining us to pre-book a slot. All our jobs will be posted on the company’s website and social media accounts.” Wrightbus is at the forefront of the zero emission public transport movement. An increase in orders has seen production at the factory double in , with zero emission vehicles accounting for an impressive  per cent of all output this year.Wrightbus boasts excellent, clean working conditions, great rates of pay and fantastic career progression opportunities. The event will take place from .-.pm on Thursday March . Half hour slots are available to pre-book at https:wrightbus.eventbrite Previous recruitment open evenings held at Wrightbus have attracted more than  people who were interested in a range of jobs including production, quality, engineering and office roles.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220330newscalls for a time to say thanks during volunteer week
story: With the countdown now on to Volunteers’ Week , which runs from - June, Volunteer Now is calling on communities and businesses across Northern Ireland to get ready to honour local heroes by taking ‘Time to Say Thanks’ as part of a week-long programme of activity celebrating volunteering across the UK.   Now in its th year, Volunteers’ Week sees charities, voluntary groups, social organisations, and volunteers themselves come together to recognise the incredible impact that volunteering has in communities, both locally and regionally. This year’s theme - ‘A time to say thanks’ – encourages everyone to recognise the huge impact that people from all walks of le make on the lives of people and their communities when they volunteer. The week-long celebration, coinciding with the Queen’s Platinum Jubilee, will include designated themed days showcasing the breadth and impact that dferent types of volunteering has played in local communities over the last  months. Each day is a chance to take the time to say thank you to volunteers across Northern Ireland – and Volunteer Now is calling for all charities and volunteers to get involved. With around , formal volunteers carrying out work with designated organisations and , informal volunteers, volunteering plays a signicant role across the region. Each year, volunteers across Northern Ireland carry out work worth more than half a billion pounds and contribute pound million to the local economy. Voluntary organisations in Northern Ireland do work worth more than half a billion pounds a year. As the lead organisation for volunteering in Northern Ireland, Volunteer Now is leading the charge to put Volunteers’ Week firmly on the community agenda, encouraging everyone to engage with the week-long programme of activity to say a collective ‘thank you’ to volunteers right across the region. Denise Hayward, chief executive at Volunteer Now, which coordinates Volunteers’ Week in Northern Ireland, commented: “Volunteers have continued to give so much time, energy, commitment and skills to the communities and organisations that they have supported through another dficult year. It is fitting that Volunteers Week  will give everyone the opportunity to say Thank You to everyone who has made a dference through their voluntary efforts.”  Volunteer Now is also calling for more people to participate in volunteering activity by registering with its online portal. Launched in , Volunteer Now’s revolutionary volunteering , in partnership with Be Collective, is celebrating its second anniversary, having registered and connected almost , volunteers with more than , organisations across a wide range of opportunities. The Be Collective  is the first of its kind to be implemented within the charity sector in Northern Ireland and aims to revolutionise volunteering and its impacts for businesses, community groups and iniduals across the region. The  cohesively connects volunteering, organisations, outcomes and social value through innovative social infrastructure and for the first time quanties volunteering contribution by giving iniduals and businesses a social “record”. “I’m delighted to celebrate the second anniversary of our Be Collective online volunteering  has really revolutionised how we connect volunteers with real time opportunities, providing support for communities across Northern Ireland and, importantly, delivering quantiable and demonstrable impact for organisations investing in their people. We’re delighted to see so many of our partners embrace this new  and we would encourage any organisation considering volunteering to get in touch with us and register with the . With a wide iety of live volunteering opportunities, there has never been a better time for volunteers, or those considering getting into volunteering, to find their perfect match”, added Denise Hayward. For more information on events planned for Volunteers’ Week in Northern Ireland, which runs from - June , please visit www.volunteernow or follow @VolunteerNow on Facebook or Instagram. For resources and more information on Volunteers’ Week UK, please visit www.volunteersweek.org

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220331newsfirmus announce another price hike this time by 16 31
story: Firmus energy has today announced an increase of .% from May ,  for gas customers in the Ten Towns area, impacting around , domestic customers. This increase will see the yearly gas bill of a typical household with a credit meter rise by about pound per year to pound,. Those customerswith a prepayment gas meterwill see costs increase by around pound per year to pound,. Raymond Gormley, Head of Energy Policy at the Consumer Council said: “It is important that consumers are made aware that their domestic gas bills will stay high for at least the next year because the wholesale price that the companies pay for the gas continues to be much more expensive than the norm. Unfortunately heating oil prices are also very high, so regardless of the fuel we use, many of us will experience extreme pressure on our household budgets. This will further increase the numbers of people in fuel poverty, as many families may struggle to find the extra money they will now need to pay for heating. “As the Winter   Emergency Fuel Payment Scheme ends today , we implore firmus energy, and the wider energy industry, to commit to financially supporting the continuation of a fuel hardship scheme in the coming financial year. For the longer term, it is clear that energy companies, policy makers, the Utility Regulator, charities and the Consumer Council must continue to work together to develop sustainable solutions to help support those in need as the problem of high energy prices will likely be with us for the foreseeable future.” Consumers who are struggling to pay their energy bills or struggling to pay to top-up their meter should contact their supplier directly for support. Consumers can also get in touch with the Consumer Council for free, independent advice by calling Freephone    or by emailingcontact@consumercouncil.org.uk. The Consumer Council’s websitehas a number of free resources includingSwitch On: A Guide for Home Energy Users,which helps consumers be more energy efficient at home, get the best from their electricity or gas supply, and save money. firmus energy customers in Greater Belfast and in the Gas to the West network area will not be impacted by this tarf change.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220401newselection set to be delayed due to ballot paper issues
story: Our story about the election being postponed for a fortnight due to insufficient amounts of the correct type of ballot paper … was an April Fool! We told you that the tree used to make ballot paper – Flora Plio – was in short supply. Of course there’s no such thing as a Flora Plio, which is an anagram of April Fool. Our paper production expert, Poppy Cox, was indeed a load of poppycock, and of course we couldn’t do an April Fool about paper without mentioning foolscap. And we had to make our ‘official’ statement at midday because,we hadn’t, we’d be the fools for carrying on!  The forthcoming election is set to be postponed for a fortnight due to insufficient amounts of the correct type of ballot paper, we understand. It is believed that the specic type of tree used to make the paper - Flora Plio – has been in short supply in recent months. Paper production expert, Poppy Cox, explained why this specic type of tree was used for the production of ballot papers. “It has a special waxy quality that prevents the mark you make on your ballot paper being rubbed out,” said Mrs Cox. “That obviously adds an added level of security to the elections and stops people claiming that their ballot has been changed.” Alternatives are now being sought and the two week delay in the vote will hopefully allow for the ballot to be printed on a dferent type of paper. “It is possible that we could see a special kind of foolscap being useda secure alternative can’t be found,” Mrs Cox added. An official statement on the matter is due to be made at midday today .

title: baked beans in a burrito theyll blow you away says mexican eatery boojum
story: Boojum#s burrito with beans FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueBoojum#s burrito with beansOlof RiplaApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailYou’ve heard of baked beans on toast, or beans on jacket potato, how about baked beans in a burrito Popular Mexican burrito chain Boojum has announced that from today all of its stores across the country will now have baked beans added to its menu due to a black bean and pinto bean shortage.The chain notied its followers via social media that baked beans will temporarily replace both black bean and pinto bean due to unforeseen supply chain dficulties. Baked beans will be the sole bean option for some time whilst the company addresses its stock issues.Robert Powell, operations manager at Boojum said: “Over the years we have introduced many new additions to the menu, however this has been something we never could have seen coming.“People may be apprehensive to try the baked beans at first but believe me, you will be blown away! Our entire team have tried the baked beans in their burritos and bowls and we honestly don’t know why we didn’t introduce this option sooner. Many of our customers already mistake pinto beans or baked beans so it was a no brainer to introduce this saucy option to the mix! We know this is a risk but after getting a unanimous thumbs up from the team during the testing phase, we are confident our customers will absolutely love this new menu item.”Rolf Paoli, long-time Boojum addict, who has already tasted this new combination said: “When I took the first bite I thought, where have you bean all my le ! title: having a laugh 10 top office themed pranks for april
story: April Fools Day prankApril Fool#s Day FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueApril Fools Day prankAmy CochraneTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailApril Fools’ Day is celebrated in cultures around the world traditionally on the first day of that month, which falls on Friday.Though its origins remain a mystery, many businesses, brands and media outlets take the opportunity to have a little fun with their customers and readers.Coca-Cola famously promoted a new avocado-flavoured drink one year, and Burger King advertised a Left-Handed Whopper, which fooled scores of customers who requested the fake burger.But the question arises year on year: how far is too far with your pranks With more of us back in the office now following lockdown, tomorrow could be a good opportunity to have a bit of fun with colleagues. But to ensure HR doesn’t come calling, here are  ways to celebrate the day without getting in trouble.: Cardboard cutoutsCardboard cutouts of celebrities — or even people you know — always manage to bring a laugh out of anyone. You can hide these behind doorways or in windows to give a shock to your colleagues. If you want to go the extra mile, why not make ones of yourself and strategically place them around the office.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up : Balloon roomWhile less infuriating than a glitter bomb, it is far easier to clean up. Filling up the conference room with balloons is a harmless and colourful prank that people can enjoy from the spectacle and effort alone.: Family swapIf you have some photo-editing skills and are in for a long-haul prank, then consider copying and Photoshopping your co-worker’s desk photos. Swap out their loved ones for one of your favourite cartoon or TV characters and see how long it takes them to notice.: Did you get my memo A classic in every sense of the word. Sticking Post-it notes all over someone’s workspace is as time-consuming as it is funny. You don’t have to stop there. You can even go as far as to cover their car in Post-it notes and see how long it takes for them to get rid of them all.: Flip the screenThe fastest prank you can do on this list, and possibly one of the longest to fixyour ‘mark’ is not computer savvy. Go to display settings and flip the computer screen horizontally so that everything is upside down. Watch and laugh as they struggle to get things back to some sort of normality.: Mouse trapAnother old school prank guaranteed to produce lots of laughs. Tape over the sensor on your co-worker’s mouse and watch as they try and figure out why their computer refuses to work.: Air hornAttaching an air horn underneath a chair or behind a door is a timeless prank. There really is nothing more satisfying or as basic as a jump scare. Nobody said April Fools’ pranks had to be high art.: He’s behind youWhile working from home, Zoom backgrounds did a lot of heavy lting in the prank department. The most creative fun you can have is to turn your remote background into a video. It can be anything from your doppelganger walking into the room, or a mysterious figure leering in the doorway.: Hot micThere’s nothing more anxiety-inducing than wonderingyour microphone is on during a meeting. One prank would be to stage this situation and make your co-workers believe that you think you’re on mute. See how long it takes for your co-workers to interrupt you and others in your household from saying some really embarrassing things.: That’s a wrapGt wrap your prank this year by wrapping all of your co-worker’s belongings in wrapping paper. It’s always the larks with the most effort put into them which are the most satisfying. So don’t skimp out on the attention to detail. title: how to spot the northern lights over northern ireland tonight
story: The Northern Lights seen over Dunluce Castle in . Photo by Jason Murphy. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe Northern Lights seen over Dunluce Castle in . Photo by Jason Murphy.Allan PrestonTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailNorthern Ireland could be one of the best places to catch an appearance of the Northern Lights this evening.The British Geological Survey have said there is now an increased chance of seeing the aurora phenomenon on Thursday evening and Friday across the UK, with those in Scotland, northern England and Northern Ireland likely to have the best opportunities.The BGS say it is easier to spot the Aurora Borealis than you might think, but it does depend on having the right conditions of having clear and dark skies.Geomagnetic Disturbance Alertth MarchBritish Geological Survey Assuming clear dark skies, there is an increased chance of seeing the aurora on st March and April st. In the UK, those in Scotland, northern England and Northern Ireland may have the best opportunities. pic psfZg— British Geological SurveyMarch , According to the BGS, the aurora is caused when there large explosions take place on the surface of the sun.This sends huge amounts of charged particles out into space, which sometimes travel towards Earth where they are captured by the magnetic field and guided towards the geomagnetic polar regions.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read MoreNorthern Ireland weather: Cold snap set for awith snow showers possibleOn their way down they are slowed by Earth’s atmosphere which acts as a shield.When the charged particles collide with gas molecules in the atmosphere, the energy released manests in bright colours.The “auroral ovals” are most often seen in northern areas like Scandinavia, Greenland, Alaska, Canada and Russia as well as southern ovals covering the Antarctic regionsWhen there is increased geomagnetic activity, the ovals widen and spread meaning it can be possible to see them further south in the UK.Speaking to the Belfast , Met Office meteorologist Sarah Kent said sky watchers in Northern Ireland would still need a good amount of luck to catch the perfect moment.“If people are feeling lucky, they should go out and wrap themselves up. Tonight we are still looking at a mixture of showers and clear spells,” she said.Initially,you’re near the north coast that’s where you’re most likely to encounter the showers and some cloudier skies.“However, the further south you are it’s more likely you’ll get some clear spells. It’s certainly worth a shotpeople are going out this evening around -pm.”Conditions for catching the Northern Lights will also be more dficult in urban areas like Belfast.You do need the clear skies, so ideally you would want the northern horizon which is clear from light pollution.You could still head out to the north coast, and while likely to get a few showers in between them it’s where you’re going to get the darkest horizon.It’s a little bit of a Catch  there. I’m sure there will be some stunning photos but people will really need to be lucky.”Most ReadBomb hoax: North Belfast gym owner appears in court charged in connection with alert at peace eventHow to spot the Northern Lights over Northern Ireland tonightHaving a laugh:  top office-themed pranks for April Fool’s DayEx-Irish badminton champ paid mums to let him abuse childrenSinn Fein slammed for election launch at Belfast’s Europa Hotel which was repeatedly bombed by IRATop Videos programme, which celebrates its th anniversary this year. Credit :Sinn FeinGarrett HarganTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA victims’ campaigner has questioned the use of the Europa Hotel as the setting for Sinn Fein’s election launch, saying it’s a venue the Provisional IRA “systematically bombed”.On Tuesday, Michelle O’Neill gave a speech at the Great Victoria Street hotel, which was bombed  times during the Troubles.She outlined Sinn Fein’s priorities ahead of the upcoming election including the cost of living crisis and “fiercely defending” the Good Friday Agreement.“The facts are that the balance of power at Stormont has shted irreversibly and political unionism must come to terms with the fact the world is moving on fast,” Ms O’Neill said.“So, while the DUP and the TUV are trying to take us backwards, our message is clear, we are only moving forward.”Commenting on the choice of venue, Kenny Donaldson, spokesman for Innocent Victims United said: Sinn Fein clearly don#t do irony, to bleat on about upholding democracy at the very venue which the Provisional IRA systematically attacked again and again, making it the most bombed hotel in Europe is brazen to say the least.However, due to the intensity of the Provisional IRA#s bombing campaign — and that of other terrorists, few hotel venues across Northern Ireland have come away unscathed by the Troubles.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up TUV South Belfast candidate Andrew Girvin said Sinn Fein’s campaign launch at the Europa was a “grotesque spectacle” given the setting.“Here we had the political wing of the terrorist organisation which repeatedly bombed the hotel in which they met daring to ponticate about democracy and respecting the will of the people.“There is nothing undemocratic about refusing to operate the Belfast Agreement structures which could foist a Sinn Fein First Minister upon Northern Ireland.“The choice of venue for this republican jamboree underscores the fact that no unionist should ever agree to take up the position of deputy to a Sinn Fein First Minister.“Yet just weeks out from the election both the DUP and UUP are dodging this vital question.Will they act as bridesmaid to Michelle O#Neill  Why is there reluctance to be open and honest with the public on this point ”The DUP#s Gordon Lyons said Sinn Fein#s election launch demonstrates their priority lies on holding a border poll rather than on helping families or rebuilding Northern Ireland’s economy.The party#s director of elections said: Sinn Fein#s rally was a show of strength for a border poll.“Whilst the DUP has a five-point plan to build a better future for Northern Ireland, Sinn Fein wants to win the election to implement their plan for a border poll.“There is a clear choice on offer to people whether they want a future focused on fixing our health system, tackling the cost of living crisis and replacing the protocol, or one fixated on a isive border poll.“When Michelle O#Neill talks about making history, we know it isn#t record levels of investment into our hospitals she is referring to. Now is not the time for ision and uncertainty.That is why this election is so important.Sinn Fein has been contacted for comment.Speaking at an election launch, Ms O’Neill said that Sinn Fein will defend but not renegotiate the Good Friday Agreement.The former Deputy First Minister said those who hanker for the past need to realise that there is no going back, only forward.Sinn Fein#s Stormont leader also described the DUP#s collapse of the Executive as political vandalism, although her own party also brought Stormont down in the same Assembly mandate.She said: When the Assembly, Executive and North South Ministerial Council were restored in January  it was with a shared commitment to deliver the public services, societal reforms and future that our people need and deserve.It was ambitious to form a five-party coalition Executive, but it was achieved, getting us back to genuine power-sharing, and thankfully so, because while everyone knew there would be challenges ahead, no one could have predicted that in only a matter of weeks that our Executive would be dealing with a global pandemic that would have such devastating impacts on every part of society, community and people#s lives and livelihoods.It is to the credit of all ministers from across the five parties that they responded and have worked with a unity of purpose, and unity of leadership for the past two years.This is what the public want to see more of — co-operation and delivery.Ms O#Neill added: Sinn Fein will be defending, not renegotiating the Good Friday Agreement now, or in the time ahead.Ms O#Neill said the May  election was the most important in a generation.Related topicsSinn FéinMichelle O#NeillIRACost of LivingTraditional Unionist VoiceGordon LyonsThe Executive OfficeMore On Sinn Speaking at the event, held at the Titanic Hotel in Belfast, Rob Heron, Managing Partner, EY Northern Ireland, said: ÒAt the start of , strong demand and high confidence levels had our EY Entrepreneur Of The Year family feeling upbeat about their prospects for the year ahead. Since then, the war in Ukraine has reminded us how fragile our world can be. It has compounded the rising cost of living, and alongside inflationary pressures and the long tail of the pandemic, the tone of the outlook for  and beyond has changed. And yet, despite all of these geopolitical complexities,we find our EOY community in their usual frame of mind, focussed on solutions and applying ingenuity, agility and determination to seek opportunities and solve problems where others see challenge.Ó The EOY programme not only recognises the work of exceptional entrepreneurs but also provides an invaluable business network and business development opportunities for entrepreneurs within a hugely supportive group.The Spring Energiser aims to drive the conversation on how entrepreneurs can tackle our worldÕs biggest challenges while also taking their businesses to the next level. Roger Wallace, Partner Lead, EY Entrepreneur Of The Year, commented: ÒIn a year that will be dominated by rising prices, every business and inidual will be looking at what they spend, where they spend it and what value they get from their purchases. Within this flux lies tremendous opportunity that many of our EOY family are already seizing. Credit: Brian Lawless PAMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe UUP manesto has enough meat to show that the party is starting to think seriously about being a major player in the Executive once more, and enough bare bones to reveal that the process is incomplete.At , words, this document is serious in its scope and suffused with the liberal unionist tone of new leader Doug Beattie.But it is what this manesto does not say which reveals most: hard choices or unpopular proposals are either absent or presented in oblique terms — and that jars with Mr Beattie’s straight-talking style.Health is the first and the iest section — unsurprisingly, given that polling has shown Robin Swann to be Stormont’s most popular minister.The manesto indicates support for radical measures, saying that the pandemic has shown that both patients and medics are willing “to travel longer distancesit means receiving care and support in a more timely manner. It is essential that the opportunities currently before us are not lost”.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read MoreNo united Ireland for generations to come, UUP leader insistsAndrew Madden:OpinionElection briefing: It’s battle stations for UUP, but indferent Tories need a nudgeThat seems to hint at support for implementing the decades of reports which say Northern Ireland has too many small hospitals, some of which need to be closed or downgraded to centralise expertise in centres of excellence.But the UUP is not explicit about this.There are other hints of centralising services — “a regionally consistent approach to cancer services across Northern Ireland” with “regional pathways and rapid diagnostic clinics”.The party also proposes greater evening and weekend use of theatres, but hints at the cost by saying it will mean “properly incentivising the move towards a genuine seven day a week health service”.Signicantly, the party says it would ban the use of contract agency workers — but only “once the immediate HSC pressures subside” .Health trusts are sharply criticised, with the UUP saying that for too long “sub-optimal trust performances [have been] tolerated”, something which suggests frustration at what Mr Swann has seen within the system.His solution is a new operationally independent HSC chief executive accountable to a board with political, professional and civic society membership, similar to the Policing Board.On the NI Protocol, the UUP says that “unionists cannot accept an internal border within the United Kingdom. There can be no border in the Irish Sea between Northern Ireland and Great Britain”.That simple commitment seems to prevent the UUP signing up to any revised protocol involving an Irish Sea border.Its tone is dferent to the DUP, talking about wanting to “maintain good relations with the EU”, but the content is similar to that of the ERG — pushing mutual enforcement, with a new north-south body to oversee this. A requirement to label GB goods coming into NI “for UK sale only” would only avoid a new Irish Sea borderit was enforced for all UK products.The party would ban gay conversion therapy, establish a gambling regulator, allocate overdue investment to football stadia, and examine letting private garages do MoT tests.The party opposes a Troubles amnesty and robustly says paramilitaries “need to be put out of business permanently” by focussing on their leaderships and criminal assets. It wants to curb legal aid, due to “the culture of lawfare which has been allowed to develop within our legal system and which has proved extremely lucrative for a number of firms”.The manesto is laden with more spending — new train stops, new busses, new roads, more rates relief for some businesses, spending on city deals,  more police officers, and looking at giving everyone in primary school a free meal.How this would be paid for is unclear. There is no talk of increasing rates. Water charges are ruled out. And giving Stormont more tax powers is also rejected. Credit: Liam McBurneySuzanne BreenTwitterEmailApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailSDLP MP Claire Hanna has spoken of her shock at a Sinn Fein proposal to abolish the constituency of South Belfast.In a submission to the Boundary Commission, the party proposes the constituency is axed with its voters largely ided between two other constituencies — despite South Belfast having more voters than either East or West Belfast.Ms Hanna said Sinn Fein’s proposal “does not make any mathematical sense” and that residents would be stunned it was seeking to abolish Northern Ireland’s most politically erse constituency.Sinn Fein has been contacted for comment.South Belfast currently is the only constituency toMLAs from five dferent parties: SDLP, DUP, Alliance, Sinn Fein and Greens.Ms Hanna said: “Each of Belfast’s four constituencies has a distinct identity, community cohesion, and things they are proud of. South Belfast has for decades been known as a erse, integrated part of the city where people of all political views and none live side-by-side.“Many people chose to settle in South Belfast precisely because of that. This constituency is, and always has been, a shared space.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “It is pluralist in its politics and values, and I think residents would be very disconcerted and concerned at a proposal to break it up and to parcel bits off into other constituencies.”Read MoreTalks need to begin over scrapping mandatory coalition, says Arlene FosterThe rules for the  Boundary Commission review mean each constituency must have an electorate of between , and ,.North Belfastand South Belfastfall within the target range. West Belfastand East Belfastdo not.Ms Hanna lodged her objections to Sinn Fein’s proposal at a meeting with the Boundary Commission last month.“West and East Belfast are below the statutory electoral range by , and , voters respectively,” she said.“The high level of house-building in South Belfast, particularly in the Four Winds and Malone, together with the council’s determination to repopulate the city core, means the number of electors in South Belfast is going to rise further within a parliamentary term.“The Boundary Commission was happy for Northern Ireland to keep all its  seats. In previous proposals in , which were dropped, it had wanted to reduce to  seats, so somewhere would have had to take the fall.“Sinn Fein’s proposal is even more surprising when the Boundary Commission isn’t even looking to lose a seat.”Under Sinn Fein’s plan, Belfast would be reduced from four constituencies to three.East Belfast would remain, absorbing parts of South Belfast, and two new constituencies would be created — North West Belfast and South West Belfast.Ormeau, Rosetta, and Ravenhill would be moved into East Belfast. Malone, Stranmillis, and Finaghy would be put into the new South West Belfast constituency.Demographic trends suggest Sinn Fein would secure both the South West and North West Belfast seats at a Westminster election, with the SDLP losing out. The influx of South Belfast voters to the east of the city would help Alliance unseat the DUP there.In its submission to the Boundary Commission, Michelle O’Neill’s party says: “Sinn Fein believe that too much emphasis is placed in trying to keep Belfast as four-seater constituency which comes at the detriment to the rest of the constituencies.”Under the Boundary Commission’s plan, South Belfast remains largely intact, but gains the rural wards of Drumbo, Saintfield, and Moneyreagh to become South Belfast and Mid Down. Strangford would be renamed Strangford and Quoile.Professor Jon Tonge of the University of Liverpool said the commission’s proposed boundary changes were “fairly minimalist”.“Fermanagh and South Tyrone — very marginal — becomes fractionally more nationalist, which will please Sinn Fein. title: sinn fein defend proposals to redraw belfasts electoral boundaries
story: Sinn Fein#s Conor Murphy. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSinn Fein#s Conor Murphy.Allan PrestonTwitterEmailApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailSinn Fein’s Conor Murphy has said redrawing Belfast’s electoral boundaries cannot be ruled out.It comes after this party made a submission to the Boundary Commission, proposing the South Belfast Westminster seat held by the SDLP’s Claire Hanna is axed, iding it between East and West Belfast.Ms Hanna said the move “does not make any mathematical sense” and that residents would be stunned by plans to abolish Northern Ireland’s most erse constituencyRead MoreSDLP MP Claire Hanna’s ‘shock’ over proposal by Sinn Fein to abolish her South Belfast seatQuestioned about it on BBC Good Morning Ulster, Mr Murphy said the proposal had been about protecting rural voters.It’s not about any single constituency,an MP or any political party approaches this on the basis of what constituency they currently hold, they’re not looking at the bigger picture,” he said.He said the boundary commission had traditionally preserved Belfast constituencies at the expense of large rural constituencies, trying to bring in rural areas to shore up Belfast numbers.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up What we’re saying to the boundary commission isyou want to look at the  constituencies across the north then look at them in their entirety. Let’s not try and put articial fixes into some constituencies and chop and change the larger rural ones west of the Bann.If that does involve some changes in the Belfast constituencies then so be it, but it needs to be an honest and scientic assessment.Not one which attempts to shore up political positions in and around the city of Belfast at the expense of rural areas.”During the interview, Mr Murphy was also askedhe believed there would still be a Stormont Executive after the Assembly election in May.This follows uncertainty over whether the DUP would accept Sinn Fein nominating a First Minister.That’s not a question for Sinn Fein, we will be in the Executive. We want to be in the Executive,” he said.We believe the best situation going forward is for all of the parties to work together.If the DUP do not want to be in an Executive they have the option to opt out of one and allow the rest of the parties to get on with the decision making.But the idea that their protest against the Protocol is having any impact on thenegotiation is risible.The actual impact it’s having is on the people we serve here, the people that we represent are suffering because we can’t get budgets done, we can’t get decisions taken.If the DUP are not prepared to go back into the Executive well don’t go back in, but don’t hold back the rest of society.”On the former First Minister and DUP leader Arlene Foster’s claim that it’s time to scrap mandatory power sharing, Mr Murphy noted that any party retained the right to opt out of the Executive.Read MoreTalks need to begin over scrapping mandatory coalition, says Arlene FosterIf the DUP, who were the party most consistently at odds with the other four parties over the course of the last two years, don’t wish to be in the Executive then that’s a matter for themselves,” he said.Mandatory coalition doesn’t mean that everyone has to be in the Executive, it’s not compulsory.It means you’re entitled to be inyou wish to be in.”On whether the DUP could end up in opposition with Sinn Fein in power, Mr Murphy said all parties working together remained the best option.Related topicsConor MurphyMore On Conor Murphy PremiumFears for Belfast economy as exodus of % of civil servants to regional hubs loomsSpring Since then, the war in Ukraine has reminded us how fragile our world can be. It has compounded the rising cost of living, and alongside inflationary pressures and the long tail of the pandemic, the tone of the outlook for  and beyond has changed. Credit: Press Eye Darren Kidd“No, we did not get everything right,” she told the audience, adding that decisions made had an impact they did not foresee.She highlighted the impact on vulnerable children kept away from school and elderly people who spent the last weeks of their lives in isolation.More broadly,some political leaders pushed back against specic advice “that was somehow endangering health and more interested in wealth”.“It was really, really unhelpful,” Mrs Foster said. “In a one-party governmentwould have been struggling but we were in a five-party coalition.” She added that some in the Executive wanted everything shut down while she advocated what she claims was a more common sense approach.“But we had to find common ground,” Mrs Foster added.On the argument made by some in the business community the region will be in a unique position with a foot in both the EU and GB, Mrs Foster said in the interview with thethat she does not agree with that point of view.She said: “No, I do not. First of all because we are part of the United Kingdom, most of our supply chain is from the UK. If you look at people who rely on goods coming — whether it is manufacturing or retail — they have to get the goods from GB into Northern Ireland and sometimes go back to GB again.“The problem is from GB to Northern Ireland and, therefore, that has to be fixed.”Mrs Foster further argued: “Economics are very important and I have always been interested in the economy of Northern Ireland...but societally this is causing real problems in Northern Ireland because people feel that their identity as citizens is being eroded.“That goes way beyond economic issues. That is a problem and therefore needs to be sorted.“You cannot separate the economy from the societal issues.” Questioned on whether other issues facing both the UK government and the EU, including the Ukraine crisis, may hold up thrashing out a deal that would essentially remove those barriers between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK, Mrs Foster said: “I would have thought the Ukraine would have pointed to a need to actually sort out these issues more so than anything .” She added: “In the sense thatyou have a sovereign country that has been invaded as you have in the Ukraine, does that not say Boris Johnson as Prime Minister should look to his sovereign borders as well and deal with the issues that are there “Yes, to me he should be dealing with the issues within his own jurisdiction.”On the Protocol protests, Mrs Foster said she will leave those to the politicians but that she has not attended any rallies — and has not been invited.The former Fermanagh-South Tyrone MLA does not believe the Executive will be up and running in the immediate aftermath of the election but that should not impact business to any great extent.“Businesses are making their decisions not on what is happening at Stormont, quite frankly, they are making their decisions on does it make good business sense, what are the costs, have we got the people, have we got the skills that we need ”More generally, she supports the X strategy, stating: “That focus on innovation is very important, to get an edge on other parts of the world, to find out niches and I think we have been quite good at that, cyber security, financial technology, creative, film and television.”Following her forced resignation nearly a year ago, Mrs Foster said she made a “a decision that I still wanted to advocate for Northern Ireland because I love the place”.She added: “I will never talk down Northern Ireland.”Related topicsArlene FosterNI ProtocolUkraineThe Executive OfficeBoris JohnsonMore On Arlene Foster Speaking at the event, held at the Titanic Hotel in Belfast, Rob Heron, Managing Partner, EY Northern Ireland, said: ÒAt the start of , strong demand and high confidence levels had our EY Entrepreneur Of The Year family feeling upbeat about their prospects for the year ahead. Since then, the war in Ukraine has reminded us how fragile our world can be. It has compounded the rising cost of living, and alongside inflationary pressures and the long tail of the pandemic, the tone of the outlook for  and beyond has changed. And yet, despite all of these geopolitical complexities,we find our EOY community in their usual frame of mind, focussed on solutions and applying ingenuity, agility and determination to seek opportunities and solve problems where others see challenge.Ó The EOY programme not only recognises the work of exceptional entrepreneurs but also provides an invaluable business network and business development opportunities for entrepreneurs within a hugely supportive group.The Spring Energiser aims to drive the conversation on how entrepreneurs can tackle our worldÕs biggest challenges while also taking their businesses to the next level. Roger Wallace, Partner Lead, EY Entrepreneur Of The Year, commented: ÒIn a year that will be dominated by rising prices, every business and inidual will be looking at what they spend, where they spend it and what value they get from their purchases. Within this flux lies tremendous opportunity that many of our EOY family are already seizing. The event today aims to give entrepreneurs the opportunity to engage with and learn from a like-minded community of brave, unrelentingly innovative thinkers that are continuously striving to meet the needs of their customers, their communities and society as a whole.Ó Other speakers at the event include Former First Minister of Northern Ireland, Arlene Foster Mark Dowds, Venture Partner at Anthemis ESB Executive Director, Marguerite Sayers Domhnal Slattery, CEO, Avalon and former Ireland International rugby player, Rory Best.
